Ran a binary equivalence check using IndexPersistBenchmark, equivalence is confirmed.

The legacy merger orders columns differently from the V9 merger, which is why the hashes differ.

Earlier I did catch an issue from this check, where this patch caused a fully null column to be erroneously written to the segment (but without appearing in index.drd), this is fixed in a new commit, with a new test added for that case.

@drcrallen thanks for the review, it was very helpful!

@gianm To avoid adding Critical calls like lifecycle.start() i decided to go other way around.

The new way to do it is to have 2 classes (`HdfsKerberosConfig` and `HadoopKerberosConfig`) that binds to the properties under the same `druid.hadoop.security.kerberos.*` that provides keytab and principal. the idea here is to avoid having druid final user configuring 2 different things for the same end goal.

Thus, if the end-user is using the HDFS storage module. The auth call will be done by lifecycle stuff and that will work fine for all the CLI that loads pdfs-storage-module like historicals/MM/Overloard . 
In the other hand if the user will be submitting hadoop job with or without hdfs-module, hadoop jobs will have to do the auth call once the new class loader is used to run the jobs anyway. The call will occur once the job calls ensurePaths.

In the end of the day user has to set the properties `druid.hadoop.security.kerberos.principal` and `druid.hadoop.security.kerberos.keytab` and druid will do the necessary auth calls under the hood.
I just pushed a small fix for a bug someone was having and rebased on master.
@fjy Seemed not and hard to maintain. Let's close this.
@fjy Yep, I've done it but this patch seemed not necessary (and hard to maintain). Let's close this.

@fjy Basically it's for regrouping/reordering the result of group-by query with different granularity with query granularity in-memory before forwarding it to client. For example, we can make a metric in day granularity. But if we need it to be sorted in a week we should do it in client or make nested-groupby query which is expensive than this (and still cannot solve some cases). We've used this once but proceeded to another way which is tied under complex tree of in-house patches.  You can close this anytime.

@drcrallen Thank you for the kind comment.
It is just for the ease of use.
However, I totally agree with you that hidden proxy inside a response is not good approach.

At first, I tried to make a monitoring class for historical nodes but it required periodical check of each node or heartbeat from each node, and I thought it is too much and status polling at user request is better. But, I still wanted to maintain one endpoint, as users want that, to obtain all the necessary information, which results in so naive code.

Then, how about tight timeout of contact to each historical node? or accept timeout value as a parameter? Or any approach to minimize the overhead of monitoring class?
@drcrallen and I'll just ping again then :)

The side effect is all query processing threads end up clogged with threads waiting for the locks, and the node is in general unable to answer queries. This is bad in a scenario where all nodes share approximately equal distribution of segments because it means no computes of that tier can be used effectively.

https://github.com/druid-io/druid/issues/3449 would have made this not as severe... maybe? (still digging)

üëç

The coordinator is not a monitoring system for Druid, it is a coordination system for segment shuffling.

If you wanted an endpoint who simply spit out a list of host:port by historical tier or something, then I could see that as being added to the coordinator. But such a thing would have to be consumed by some sort of polling service.

There are various items `io.druid.server.metrics.HistoricalMetricsMonitor` provides on a heartbeat basis if you don't want a polling service. I think the thing you are looking for is emitted as `segment/used` per datasource? So you simply sum up the amount emitted to get a gauge for the total on-disk size of the historical cache.

`io.druid.server.coordination.ZkCoordinator#start` calls `io.druid.server.coordination.ZkCoordinator#loadLocalCache` which does the actual segment loading, including calling `segment.getSize()` on every segment it can find in the local cache. It does this as fast as its little disk can read the data, even more so if `druid.segmentCache.numBootstrapThreads` is set.

From our side, any solution that tries to even more eagerly set `curSize` as seen by the coordinator would need to not interfere with the already long task of `ZkCoordinator#start`. If you're concerned about the coordinator doing things when the cache has not been fully initialized, then there can be steps taken to mitigate that effect.

@drcrallen good catch! I didn't understand before your comment how this part of code could cause a dead lock.

For readers who still don't understrand: who locks in `getCacheMap()` methods are taken from `Striped nsLocks` (hash-based, i. e. unordered) => two threads could try to acquire two different locks from `nsLocks` in different order and deadlock each other on the second step (line 170 in the stacktraces in the first message in this thread). There is a pattern to avoid deadlocks of this kind: http://tutorials.jenkov.com/java-concurrency/deadlock-prevention.html#ordering

updated the fix to start the supervisor first and then persist the spec if it succeeds otherwise write tombstone to prevent it being from picked up again.

@sirpkt overall patch seems fine, just to make sure It does introduce any performance regression, can you run the Select & Search query benchmarks with and without the patch.

We had `extensions/druid-hdfs-storage/*` in our classpath which made druid try to initialize the hdfs extension (even though it's not in the extensions-list). Removing this fixed the issue.

See also: https://groups.google.com/forum/?utm_medium=email&utm_source=footer#!msg/druid-development/-vULOHhL5cI/hvPTou4sAQAJ
I know that there are two ways to submit , eg : tranquility and kafka-ingestion . But I want to know the cause of the error , thx
I got it !

IIRC, the reason for NoneShardSpec is to have the coordinator compact them, as the coordinator only compacts segments with NoneShardSpec. 
forceExtendableShardSpecs with default to false is a good workaround until the coordinator logic is modified to handle numbered/linear shard specs.
Fwiw, in clustered mode, deep storage needs to be configured to a distributed file system which is accessible by all the druid nodes. try changing your deep storage to hdfs or s3.

This is just an overall comment, but the overriding of things like memory usage on a per-task basis actually breaks the encapsulation and control that the middle manager has over the resources used on its machine.

That is, it is now possible for someone external from the system to set properties that effectively stop other people from being able to schedule and run other tasks.  It looks like that capability was already introduced in #1604 so this isn't anything new.  I'm fine with it going in, but I wanted to call out that this is something we are exposing now.

@pjain1 what you are describing sounds like the intended behavior- once messages up to offset X are read, the tasks should wait for offset X+1 to appear. If no new messages ever appear then they will wait indefinitely.

Maybe what you want is #3195?

Actually #3195's problem statement is not exactly what I think your problem is, but the solution might be the same. The solution could be an API that resets a supervised Kafka ingestion to the start/end of a topic (adjusting datasource metadata as needed).
#3195 is exactly what I am trying to define here, sorry if the explanation was not clear.
fixed by #3403, according to that issue's top comment.

@pjain1 awesome - I'll close this issue since it's a duplicate of #3195 and will look into adding the reset API soonish; but like you mentioned, in the meantime you can get around this by removing the row for that datasource from the druid_dataSource table. Presumably in production this wouldn't be happening regularly, only in testing.

nishantmonu51, thank you for explain.

I have create user for druid, user for hdfs, copy all *-site.xml files to _common/, add hdfs storage path to my config files, and starting druid under druid user. Now, i have working "cluster" with two middlemanager and historical nodes.   

only one question, i have used cloudera as my hadoop distribution, and i am adding and removing nodes, very often, can i add new xml files to common when druid is working, or i must restart all nodes after each change?

I believe you need not restart your middlemanagers, It should get picked up for the new tasks since each task is a separate VM. 
To make things more cleaner, You can also use the classpathPrefix property in the task and have versioned configs for your directoryStructure. 
e.g. you can have a directory structure hadoopConfigs/v1 and when you make a change create a new directory hadoopConfigs/v2. and point new tasks to use the new classpath by setting classpathPrefix to hadoopConfigs/v2.
